article.p: Why BCHS? Because the open Internet is damn inhospitable.

section.p: OpenBSD. Why? Documentation. Security. Reliable six-month releases. It takes the guess-work out of your environment.
Resources: man pages, FAQ, Absolute OpenBSD.
C is a straightforward, non-mustachioed language. And it's portable to every system with a C compiler, which is pretty much every system.
OpenBSD's own simple, home-grown web server. If you need more features for your web application, start rethinking.
SQLite is light-weight, file-based database. And it's bundled with OpenBSD.

article.aside: BCHS isn't just a software stack. It's stable, developer-oriented tools for handling data in a hostile environment. Get used to minimalism: statically-compiled, privilege-separated binaries in file-system jails. Use powerful system tools directly instead of depending on PHP to hold your hand. And most of all, forget your LAMP instincts to desperately Google and StackExchange every parameter: man pages are your new best friend.

footer.div: Built on OpenBSD: greasy fingers, greasy spine.
